title: US jobs growth strengthens Fed's case for rate rises
text:
Good evening,

Today's much stronger than expected US jobs report reinforces the US Federal Reserve's plan to increase interest rates, despite the prospect of slower growth as a result of the war in Ukraine.

The closely watched non-farms payroll data showed 678,000 jobs were added in February, much higher than the 423,000 expected by analysts and more than January's upwardly revised 481,000. The unemployment rate fell from 4 per cent in January to 3.8 per cent.

Fed chief Jay Powell told Congress this week that the combination of employment gains and increasing inflation supported his case for a quarter-point interest rate increase as the first step in a “series” of rises this year.

Today's report also showed monthly wage growth flatlining after a jump the previous month, meaning hourly earnings have risen 5.1 per cent over the past year. Wages have soared in recent months as labour shortages prompt businesses to increase pay to fill a near-record number of vacancies. US businesses reported 10.9mn unfilled positions at the end of last year.

Similarly in the UK, labour shortages are feeding through to trade union demands for better pay deals, prompting strikes from universities to the London Underground, as our Big Read details. Wages for most people are failing to keep pace with galloping living costs, a situation set to worsen with next month's jump in UK energy prices, fuelling anger among lower-paid key workers.

Some groups, such as academics, see it as payback time. “The experience of the pandemic has alienated staff even further,” said one activist. “People were working really hard to keep the show on the road and not getting any consideration back. There was a real sense of disrespect, that our goodwill was not being reciprocated.”

The coronavirus crisis has, however, fuelled some positive trends in the labour market. Columnist Sarah O'Connor talks to Harvard's Claudia Goldin in the latest instalment of our Economists Exchange series about the pandemic's impact on the gender pay gap and how the shift to flexible working has made top jobs more compatible with family life.

“Greedy” jobs is Goldin's term for describing careers in lucrative fields such as finance, law, accounting or engineering that may pay more for longer hours or for those willing to work at weekends or during holidays — jobs that the on-call, at-home parent couldn't possibly take. “In that sense,” she argues, “the flexible work has been made more productive, greedy work has been made less greedy, and that will be a very good thing.”

Latest news

  • Microsoft became the latest tech company to suspend product sales in Russia

  • The UN said the number of Ukrainians running from conflict to neighbouring countries had now passed 1.3mn

  • Switzerland said it would freeze Russian-owned crypto assets

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

Business and economic pressure on Vladimir Putin and his allies has intensified. The US announced new sanctions on Russian oligarchs, Europe is grabbing their superyachts and the UK is drawing up plans to seize their property without compensation. Canada became the first country outside Ukraine to put tariffs on Russian imports and remove Russia's “most-favoured nation” trade status. Here's our updated list of global sanctions.

Commodities markets continue to be roiled by the conflict, with wheat prices hitting new highs as exports from Ukraine and Russia ended. Overall commodities prices are now at their highest level since 2008.

In energy news, oil prices passed $114 a barrel and stocks fell after a fire broke out at a Ukraine nuclear plant, while natural gas hit another record. The International Energy Agency set out a plan to reduce Europe's gas imports from Russia, something the FT Editorial Board said was urgently needed. Brussels is aiming to double its gas storage by next winter. The White House however rejected a ban on Russian oil imports into the US, saying an embargo would limit global supply and raise prices for consumers. Here's our explainer on the issue.

Listen back to yesterday's Twitter discussion with FT specialists on how the war is affecting the global economy.

Latest for the UK and Europe

The FT Editorial Board said a proposed online sales tax would not be enough to save UK high streets, arguing instead for more holistic reforms that could fund reduced business rates for stores without undue complexity and cost. Chancellor Rishi Sunak is planning an overhaul of R&D tax credits after criticism they were a “costly failure”.

A report from the Health Foundation charity suggests inequality and the government's austerity programme of 2010 have undermined targets for UK life expectancy and made its stated task of “levelling up” much more difficult.

Inflation in Turkey hit 54.4 per cent in February, the fastest rise in 20 years, driven by a currency devaluation. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has ordered interest rates to stay at 14 per cent, is betting that the weaker currency will boost exports and fuel economic growth ahead of a general election next year.

French president Emmanuel Macron launched his re-election bid, promising more tax cuts and investment in new industries. You can follow the race with our opinion poll tracker.

Global latest

Inflation is likely to rise faster as the war in Ukraine drives up energy prices, a view reflected everywhere from UK finance chiefs to the head of Norway's oil fund. Economics editor Chris Giles says the west's finance ministries and central banks have a difficult task ahead in managing economies already struggling to control rising prices.

China's National People's Congress convenes in Beijing on Saturday, but it is being overshadowed by international condemnation of President Xi Jinping's support for Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the worsening Covid situation in Hong Kong. Chinese amateur investors are driving up the price of stocks in little-known logistics companies in anticipation of closer Beijing-Moscow trade ties.

Argentina secured a $45bn deal with the IMF to restructure its 2018 bailout, which the fund said would “address the country's most-pressing economic challenges” and improve public finances. Argentina's congress and the IMF board must approve the details.

Wealth correspondent and personal finance editor Stefan Wagstyl examines the case for investing in emerging markets and the heightened emphasis on political concerns following the invasion of Ukraine. The country's former finance minister Natalie Jaresko has called for investors to “walk the walk” on the social and governance violations that the invasion represented.

Need to know: business

The stampede to exit Russia was joined by professional services groups Accenture and McKinsey, lettings company Airbnb and media group ITV, which said it would stop selling its shows there. Here's a round-up of other western brands leaving Russia.

Russian-owned or linked companies continue to be targeted by the international community. The London Stock Exchange has suspended 27 companies with Russian ties, Aeroflot has been dropped from Sabre and Amadeus airline ticketing systems and Russian-Israeli billionaire Roman Abramovich has put Chelsea football club up for sale.

Non-Russian companies are also feeling the effect. Calstrs, the second-biggest public pension plan in the US, has become one of the first large pension funds to confirm heavy losses on its Russian investments, while Citigroup warned it risked losing $4bn from Russia exposure. Japanese airlines are having to reroute for fear of flying over Russian airspace.

The situation has also exacerbated the semiconductor crisis as the supply of rare gases, such as neon, for the manufacturing process comes under threat due to Ukraine producing 50 per cent of global supplies. Lex looks at how industries from retail to financial services see vertical integration as a way round the supply chain squeeze.

Britain's gambling sector is enjoying mixed fortunes. Entain, owner of high street gambling stores Ladbrokes and Bwin, said business was close to pre-crisis levels, as it reported a 125 per cent jump in pre-tax profits to £393mn. However. Bet365 said the pandemic had had a “significant impact” with profits down 40 per cent compared with 2019, resulting in a pay cut for chief executive Denise Coates, one of the country's best-remunerated executives.

Science round up

Epidemic expert Richard Hatchett told the FT that governments needed to invest billions to prevent the next pandemic and set up a library of vaccines for every single family of viruses.

One of the most serious consequences of the pandemic has been the backlog in elective care. The UK NHS is using new software from US company Palantir to clear some of the lists of people waiting for treatment. Separately, the company has attracted concerns from privacy campaigners over its links to national security agencies.

The first instalments of our new series on innovation in European healthcare explain why data sharing holds the key to progress on rare diseases and details the tussle between the pharma industry and campaigners over lessons to be learned from Covid-19.

The findings from a report shared with the FT by the Nuffield Trust, a London-based health think-tank, offer the most detailed account yet of how different health systems have performed during the pandemic. All are dealing with backlogs of postponed treatment but the UK was much less prepared than its peers when the crisis struck.

And finally . . . 

The courage displayed by Volodymyr Zelensky since Russia invaded his country has been remarkable and surprised many, given his past life as a comedian, writes US editor-at-large Gillian Tett as she recalls a surreal lunch with the Ukrainian president.
